docs.snippet: THE MAN WHO KEPT THE SECRETS, by Thomas Powers. (Pocket, $3.50.) A history of the C.I.A., centering on the career of Richard Helms, chief of the organization from 1966 to 1973, that raises disturbing questions about the proper role of such an orga...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE MAN WHO KEPT THE SECRETS, by Thomas Powers. (Pocket, $3.50.) A history of the C.I.A., centering on the career of Richard Helms, chief of the organization from 1966 to 1973, that raises disturbing questions about the proper role of such an organization in a democracy. Our reviewer John le Carre called it ''a splendid spy story, the best I have read in a long time.'' THE PRODIGAL WOMEN, by Nancy Hale. (Avon, $3.50.) The confusions and torments, the high hopes, achievements and failures of a group of ''free, unshackled and adventurous girls'' growing into womanhood in Boston, New York and a sleepy Virginia town during the nowfabulous 1920's. This newly reissued 1942 novel by an accomplished writer provides rich dabs of nostalgia and some provocative comparisons with the present.

docs.snippet: Oscar de la Renta believes so strongly in the need for fresh summer dresses for all those parties and festive weekends starting with Memorial Day that he always plans a formal fashion show to present his warm-weather clothes. Besides, the deadline...
docs.lead_paragraph: Oscar de la Renta believes so strongly in the need for fresh summer dresses for all those parties and festive weekends starting with Memorial Day that he always plans a formal fashion show to present his warm-weather clothes. Besides, the deadline of the show itself helps him pull his thoughts together, he insists. Albert Capraro, who was his assistant before opening his own business and attracting such loyal fans as Betty Ford, apparently absorbed some of his fervor. Mr. Capraro also has a formal show. Don Sayres added casual separates to his repertory last fall -he had specialized in coats and suits - and feels his type of cheerful, easy playclothes is particularly appropriate for the leisure hours of summer. Adri lives in a spacious, contemporary loft that has been much photographed by design publications. She decided it would provide a good background for her informal clothes.

headline.main: ON SEVENTH AVENUE, A FORETASTE OF SUMMER

docs.snippet: The National Football League has a security force here numbering 250 in and around its headquarters at the Hyatt Regency Hotel, across from the Louisiana Superdome. The most carefully guarded object is the trophy that will be presented to the winn...
docs.lead_paragraph: The National Football League has a security force here numbering 250 in and around its headquarters at the Hyatt Regency Hotel, across from the Louisiana Superdome. The most carefully guarded object is the trophy that will be presented to the winning team in a ceremony immediately after Sunday's Super Bowl game. The trophy was named for the late Vince Lombardi before the fifth Super Bowl game, in 1971. In appearance it is essentially the same one that Lombardi and his Green Bay Packers won in the first two Super Bowls.

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: For the past year, fashion designers in New York and California have been saying that business, despite the recession, has been booming. Last night at the Kennedy Center Inaugural Ball, it was easy to see what they meant. All the fruits of their l...
docs.lead_paragraph: For the past year, fashion designers in New York and California have been saying that business, despite the recession, has been booming. Last night at the Kennedy Center Inaugural Ball, it was easy to see what they meant. All the fruits of their labor, it seemed, were being worn by women there, not only in celebration of the Republican victory but also in emulation of a kind of woman who, for them, represents a new ideal. She is not from the East, she prefers to dress opulently and she is currently represented by Nancy Reagan as well as a number of other women from the Midwest, Southwest and South.

headline.main: A NEW OPULENCE TRIUMPHS IN CAPITAL

byline.original: By JOHN DUKA, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: They came from Newport Beach, Calif., and Newport, R.I., from backwater towns and bedroom communities to celebrate the Inauguration of President Reagan. And they brought all the clothes they could carry and wore most of them. The celebrants had ri...
docs.lead_paragraph: They came from Newport Beach, Calif., and Newport, R.I., from backwater towns and bedroom communities to celebrate the Inauguration of President Reagan. And they brought all the clothes they could carry and wore most of them. The celebrants had risen to the occasion in style. And judging from the attire worn at the events of the past three days one could further say that this is not going to be a cloth coat Republican Administration.

byline.original: By JOHN DUKA, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: LAST February, the Metropolitan Opera unleashed a new production of Verdi's ''Un Ballo in Maschera'' and won howls of anguish for its pains. A few critics found the decision to accept the Boston setting foisted on Verdi by the censors, but to upda...
docs.lead_paragraph: LAST February, the Metropolitan Opera unleashed a new production of Verdi's ''Un Ballo in Maschera'' and won howls of anguish for its pains. A few critics found the decision to accept the Boston setting foisted on Verdi by the censors, but to update that setting to the Revolutionary period, to be thought-provoking. Others liked some of Elijah Moshinsky's tableaus, in conjunction with Peter Wexler's scenery of stark, slatted wooden panels and the sumptuous costumes of Peter J. Hall. But most found the production clumsy, willful and illogical.

docs.snippet: In white and black tie, in sequins and sables and clouds of perfume, Republican revelers stepped out tonight to the most lavish series of inaugural balls ever held in the nation's capital.   It was an evening of shiny black limousines and nostalgi...
docs.lead_paragraph: In white and black tie, in sequins and sables and clouds of perfume, Republican revelers stepped out tonight to the most lavish series of inaugural balls ever held in the nation's capital. It was an evening of shiny black limousines and nostalgic swing bands, of glittery Hollywood celebrities and wealthy Western oil men. The aura of big money was everywhere - expensive gowns by James Galanos, Bill Blass and Oscar de la Renta, unprecedented $100 tickets to dance to the music of Count Basie and other big bands. But mostly, it was President Reagan's evening. ''I see this as the introduction of an era of hope and promise,'' Lloyd Hand, a Los Angeles business executive who was preparing to attend the festivities, said jubilantly. ''He has a unique opportunity.''

headline.main: GLITTERING FESTIVITIES USHER IN REAGAN ERA

docs.snippet: The people in Washington are very different from you and me. They are healthy, pink-cheeked and polite. They are not opposed to sharing cabs with total strangers. And there is a certain kind of cultural homogeneity here, a pervasive upper-middle-c...
docs.lead_paragraph: The people in Washington are very different from you and me. They are healthy, pink-cheeked and polite. They are not opposed to sharing cabs with total strangers. And there is a certain kind of cultural homogeneity here, a pervasive upper-middle-class suburban conservatism in dress and carriage that is quite unlike New York eclecticism.

headline.main: THE KEY TO A CODE IN CAPITAL; WASHINGTON

docs.snippet: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt AMERICAN TONGUE AND CHEEK. A Populist Guide to Our Language. By Jim Quinn. 219 pages. Pantheon. $11.95.   JIM QUINN, a poet who writes lively food columns for Philadelphia Magazine and The SoHo Weekly News, has been br...
docs.lead_paragraph: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt AMERICAN TONGUE AND CHEEK. A Populist Guide to Our Language. By Jim Quinn. 219 pages. Pantheon. $11.95. JIM QUINN, a poet who writes lively food columns for Philadelphia Magazine and The SoHo Weekly News, has been browsing through old language books, among them Otto Jespersen's ''A Modern English Grammar on Historical Principles'' (1909, 1931; revised edition, 1947), ''considered the best scholarly grammar of our language''; Thomas R. Lounsbury's ''The Standard of Usage in English'' (1908), a surprisingly modern discussion of language by ''the dean of American grammar in his day''; and the Oxford English Dictionary, that ''monumental work of scholarship that defines words according to historical principles - by giving examples of how the words were actually used in the literature of our language.''

docs.snippet: Miro Teixeira is a young man so on the go that his body inclines forward at the waist like a racer straining for the finish line. Until recently, Brazilian politicians with his kind of ambition were simply leaning into space.   Now, however, free ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Miro Teixeira is a young man so on the go that his body inclines forward at the waist like a racer straining for the finish line. Until recently, Brazilian politicians with his kind of ambition were simply leaning into space. Now, however, free elections for every office except President have been set, and the 35-year-old Mr. Teixeira and thousands of other candidates across the country are off and running. The voting will not take place until November 1982, but people in public life are making up for a lot of lost time. It has been 15 to 18 years since Brazilians were permitted to choose state governors.

headline.main: BRAZIL OFF AND RUNNING FOR '82 ELECTION

byline.original: By WARREN HOGE, Special to the New York Times
